moves.1. Nf3 Nf6 2. d4 d5 3. e3 c5 4. b3: I've been experimenting with this Zukertort setup.
moves.4... cxd4 5. exd4 Bg4 6. Be2 e6 7. Bb2 N: Both sides have completed development.  White controls e5, while Black counters with control of e4.
moves.10... Qc7 11. h3 Bh5 12. Rc1 Ne7 13. Ne5: White has planted a N on e5; Black will try to remove it.
moves.14... Ng6 15. Ndf3 Nh5 16. Nxg6 fxg6: I was expecting hxg6.  The text drops a pawn.
moves.17. Qxe6+ Kh8 18. Qe2 Rae8 19. Ne5 Bxe5: This sets up a pawn fork, at the cost of exposing White's K.
moves.21. g4 Rg5 22. Qe3 Rf8: I was expecting h6 to protect the R.  This has to be classified as a blunder as it drops an entire R.
moves.23. Qxg5 Nf4: There are two good threats here: 1) Nxh6, forking K and Q, 2) Ne2+, forking K and R.
moves.24. Qh4 Qc6: White dealt with the Nxh3+ threat, but Black decides to play for a g2 checkmate.  Ne2+ wins the exchange and recovers some of the material deficit.
moves.26. Qg3: The checkmate threat is easily countered.
moves.28... Rf3 29. Qg2: Black resigned here.  Black has a significant material deficit and White can now exchange down into a comfortably won endgame.
